- HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 13, 1928

LEVERING FUND AT
HALF WAY MARK
Campaign May be Extended;
Decision Today
CAMPUS

TOTAL

$32 39

Special Gifts Committee Has
Raised $47,030
$118,890 has been raised for the
Levering Hall Building Fund up
to one o'clock yesterday. This
total exceeds the half-way mark
by approximately $7000, $225,000
being the goal of the campaign.
The grand total at the end of
the first day's work was about
$80,000, the next day it jumped
to $89,857, then to $107,852 and
yesterday to the figures -quoted
above. These statements include
the nucleus of $60,000 with which
the campaign started.

NEWS-LETTER TO
BANQUET THURSDAY
Members of the NEWSLETTER Will hold their annual
banquet at Miller Brothers'
Restaurant on Thursday,
March 15 at 6:15 P. M. The
entire business, editorial, and
photographic staffs are expected to be present. Everyone is urged to be present on
time, as elections for all major offices will be held before
the banquet.

Second Engineering
Lecture Delivered

MUSICAL CLUBS
BANQUET AT "EMERSON"

Speeches

Theodore Roosevelt McKeldin
addressed the workers at a luncheon meeting Thursday afternoon.
Rabbi Rosenau talked to the
campaigners yesterday at noon,
commenting upon the universal
Spirit of the Y. M. C. A. and the
extent to which Johns Hopkins
University has exalted the name
of Baltimore. Dr. Rosenau said:
If it were not for the Johns Hopkins University Baltimore would
not be very important on the map
of the globe and, therefore, it is
the duty of the Baltimore citizenry to support this drive, which
will aid the University." Dr.
Rosenau told how much the old
Levering Hall meant to students
When he was a post-graduate in
1894.

THE CHAMPION

Officers for Coming Season
Elected—Varsity Seals
Awarded to Seniors
E. Bennett Kolb was unanimously chosen president of the Musical
Clubs for the year 1928-29 at the
annual banquet held at the Emerson Hotel on last Friday evening.
At the same time, also, McCall and
Kriel were elected Junior Managers
for the coming year.
Osmar P. Steinwald, retiring
president, explained that it would
be necessary to diverge from this
year's policy in that it would be impossible to select a man possessing
enough musical ability to assume
the office of musical director. For
this reason it was deemed wise to
revert to the old policy of electing
a president with two junior managers to assist him in his work.

Mr. F. N. Speller, Metallurgical
Engineer, National Tube Co., delivered the second of the series
of lectures on Engineering Practice in Room 110 Mechanical and
Electrical Engineering Building
on Friday.
Mr. iSpeller's subject was "Engineering Corrosion Problems."

PRICE 5 CENTS

BARNSTORMERS'
CAST SELECTED
Most of Important Roles
Picked by Coach Swindell
BOYNTON TO PLAY LEAD
Publicity and Business Staffs
Also Preparing for Play

"Benny" Boynton who will star in
The Annual Barnstormers Play

TRACK TEAM RAPIDLY
ROUNDING INTO SHAPE
Candidates Showing Good
Form in Weights and
Sprints

"Benny" Boynton will play the
leading role in the annual Barnstormer production, "The Champion," to be given at the Lyric on
Friday and Saturday evenings,
March 24-25. The remainder of
the more important roles have been
chosen by the coach, "Pop" Swindell; but who will appear in several of the minor parts is as yet undecided.
"The Champion" is a comedy of
English family life and is purported
to be the best ever selected by the
club. The plot hinges on the return of the prodigal son, but has
many clever situations that make it
unique.
Boynton will play the part of
William Burroughs, the Champion.
Other important roles 'that have
been decided on are:
Other Roles

John Burroughs, the father—H.
R. Warfield.
George Burroughs, the elder
brother—Donald White.
Lady Elifabeth Gallton—Donald
Ha me.
Antoinette, the French maid— •
Howard Caplan.
Mary, a younger sister—Roswell
Jones.
Mooney, the inn-keeper—Jerome
Natt.
Lord Brocklington—William B.
Banks.
There are several more roles, undecided as yet, that will be announced later. There are seventeen speaking parts ,altogether.
The opening curtain rises on a
scene in the Burroughs home in
Knotley, England. There are three
acts, and the setting for all. three is
laid in the same home.
When the play opens Mrs. Burroughs receives, through indirect
channels, a letter from her son, William, played by Boynton, who has
run away from home some fifteen
years ago, and who has been heard
from only occasionally in the long
interim. The prodigal, himself, follows in the wake of his letter and is
greeted joyfully by his mother. But
John Burroughs, the father, cannot
overcome his English obstinacy and
conservatism, thoroughly aroused
by his son's appearance. The reason is obvious; the wanderer walks
in with a swagger, "stylishly" dressed in the manner of America's
younger set. The fact is, he has
just returned from America.

With the first meet rapidly approaching, Coach Ridgely Edwards
is gradually getting his team into
shape. According to Edwards, about
forty-five or fifty men have reported
intermittently for practice, a number of which greatly please him.
This week the candidates will be
put through their paces and will be
selected for places, according to
their work at this time.
Several men have shown up very
well, Hershey, Bernstein, Yellott,
Kelly, Schiebel, W. Scheidt, Ness,
Long, and Newell, being mentioned
in this connection. In commenting
on the men, the track mentor said
that Hershey has exceeded expectations in the jumps, and is performing creditably: Yellott also

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 13, 1928

JUNIORS TO BANQUET
AT NEW HOWARD
Dr. Wight to Act as Toastmaster at Class Dinner on
March 29

•••••

Banquet season will get under
way on March 29 with the festivities of the Junior class.
The banquet, as has been previously announced, will be held at
the New Howard Hotel at seven
o'clock. Dr. Wight has been chosen toastmaster, and other speakers will be the various class officers and entertainers.
The price this year has been
set at three dollars per plate. A
man selected from each fraternity
has been placed in charge of the
tickets for this affair. These men,
upon obtaining the money; will
procure from Howard Caplan
tickets to be returned to the men
in their respective chapters upon
payment of the assessment. Samuel Hecht may also be seen in the
matter of procuring tickets.
Browne Hammond,in charge of
the entertainment committee, has
announced that Lewis Lewellyn,
of Musical Club fame, will present
several solo numbers.
To Have Dancer

A dancer has also been procured,
and from present announcements
will revive those good 'ole traditions so dear to the hearts of every
!Hopkins man, and according to
iFrisch may even establish a few
;new precedents. Other features
:have been arranged, making this
year's affair more pleasing than
'ever.
Frisch is extremely desirous
that every Junior pay up immediately so that a dependable!lumber
may be counted upon.

Cage May Be Built,
According To Rumor
Basketball Popular, Showing
Large Profit for Season

TENNIS PRACTICE TO
BEGIN TODAY
Kenneth C. Proctor, captain
of the tennis team, has announced that the first practice
would be held today at the
Fifth Regiment Armory at
two o'clock. Practice will be
held on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. All candidates are urged to enter the
indoor tournament at the Fifth
in order to get practice, as the
team will not have the use of
the Armory at that time.

TAU BETA PI INITIATIONS
FEATURE ASSEMBLY
Six Men Announced as New
Initiates; Mr. Walter Pagon
Also Talks
Tau Beta Pi announced the
names of six men as its initiates
at last week's assembly. The
names, as announced by Professor
A. G. Christie, who took charge
of the honorary fraternity's ceremonial part of the assembly, are:
Potter, Electrical Engineer;
Merman, Electrical
Engineer;
Hartig, Civil Engineer; Johnston,
Chemical Engineer; Roseman,
Chemical Engineer, and Nelson,
Mechanical Engineer.
To be eligible for the spring
election of the honorary organization, according to Professor
Christie,- a student must not only
be among the highest graded
eight of the senior class, but must
also be actively, interested in extra-curricular work. In the fall
selection of students, however,
those eligible are the seniors
whose grades place them in the
highest four of the class, and the
three highest graded members of
the Junior class.

It has been rumored that Hopkins will have a "cage" some time
in the near future. The impressive
showing the basketball team has
made during the past season has
proved conclusively that there is
ample material for a ranking team
at Hopkins—the most pressing need
now is for a place in which to practice and to hold games.
Gymnasium Past

The day of the gymnasium is
fast nearing its end because of the
great amount of floor space and
money wasted on special equipment
which is seldom used. The "cage"
—which is merely one immense well
lighted room—is taking the place of
the "gym."
Dr. Goodnow, Dean Ames, and
the Board of Trustees have been
approached on the matter, but as
yet nothing definite has been decided upon. Several different types
are under consideration by those interested, none of which entail a great
amount of expense. Dr. Van Orman and Mr. Henry Iddins are unofficially in charge of the project,
but neither of them would make
any statement on the matter with
the exception that "it looks as
though we might have one."

Following the Tau Beta Pi announcement, Mr. William Walter
Pagon, who was the chief speaker
at the assembly, spoke on "Ships
Lighter Than Air," a subject concerning which he is very familiar.
The speaker gave a lecture, which
was supplemented by a series of
photographs.
'
Among the many interesting
points which Mr. Pagon emphasized was the necessity of light
but strong material in the construction of dirigibles. Mr. Pagon stated that, though the construction is very rigid, it has been
known in some cases to crumble
under the weight of an average
person.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 13, 1928

SCRIMMAGES HELD IN
LACROSSE PRACTICE
Many New Prospects Show
Good Form in Practice
"Scrimmages during the past
week, mainly for the purpose of getting a line on the new men, have
been of great value in showing what
we may expect in the way of
reserve material for this year and
filling vacant positions next season,"
Coach Ray Van Orman, Jay stick
mentor, said today.
"Although it should be understood that no positions are absolutely secure, what we need is strong
reserve men to carry us through the
coming hard season, in which every
lacrosse team in the country is out
for Hopkins' scalp. If Hopkins,
intercollegiate champions for the
past two years, is defeated, every
coach feels confident that the Olympics will follow."
Thirty Candidates

With more than thirty candidates
out and working hard, the Jay mentors are having a difficult job to
keep an eye on every man. However, Coaches Schmeisser, Van Orman and Darley are giving every
man a chance in scrimmage and
watching every ambitious stick
wielder carefully.
The job of net guardian, which
until this year has literally gone
begging, is being hotly contested for
by Irving Gordon, Brownley, and
Frank Cone. Cone, who is a younger brother of Max Cone, former
jay home, and Sydney Cone, clever
goalie of '25, has been displaying
clever stick work in scrimmages.
Two years ago as Park School goalkeeper he was second to none in
prep school ranks. •
In the close defense positions,
Houston, Powell, Smith, and Towlin are holding their own against
regular attackers. Houston, football end, is displaying exceptional
footwork. Powell, another football
man, is proving a veritable barrier
with his weight and speed.
On the wing defense Dal Strader,
who is just learning the stick game,
George Armstrong, and Martin Elliot are showing up well.
New Attack Men

For the attack positions Bobby
Lyons, who is also just being initiated into lacrosse; Howard Caplan,
Diffenback, Dill, and Slingluff assure coaches ample strong reserve
material. Both Caplan and Lyons
are displaying the same spirit and
talent with the stick as they did
with the pigskin.
Of last year's regulars, only
Morrill and Robinson will be out of
the line-up this spring. George
Helfrish, however, who showed
such exceptional skill two years ago
at first attack, is out again for his
old position and Caplan bids fair to
develop into a first-class third attack.

DORM DOINGS

FRANCES T. BANNON
Successor to HARBAUGH & BANNON

The recent action of the Board of
Trustees to call the dormitory
"Alumni Memorial Hall" came as a
shock to the residents. It will require several years at least for
"hall" to take the place of "dorm."
As an aid to the reformation we
suggest changing the heading of
this column from "Dorm Doings"
to "Hall Hearings" or its equivalent.
Most of the residents will agree that
the term dormitory was a misnomer
for Alumni Memorial Hall. It is
probably safe to state that the average night's rest of a resident
amounts to less than six hours. The
graduate students are the ones who
really pull the average up to six.
Graduates have been known to sleep
for days at a time. When the new
plan is well under way and only
graduates inhabit Alumni Memorial
Hall, the term dormintory will be
quite proper.

BOOKS

Third Act

The curtain rises on the third act.
What a change! English conservatism has been displaced by the flambuoyant artistry in furnishings attributed to America's newly rich.
The townspeople have gathered at
the Burroughs' home for a banquet
in honor of the Chantpion. "Drink
and be merry" seems to be the slogan of everyone in the house.
The action culminates in a fight
between William and Lord Brocklington, the latter the unscrupulous
executor of the fair Lady Elizabeth's estate. Need it be stated who
is the victor? The play ends happily, as it should ; and the Champion and Lady Elizabeth, now his
betrothed, are to make their home
in America.
The less widely advertised staffs
of the Barnstormers have been
quietly but efficiently going about
their various tasks. The scenery
has been completed and is now being painted by Bill Banks. The surprising speed shown in the completion of the "flats" is due to the
fine work of George Berry, production manager, Clyde Friz, property
manager, and their various assistants.
Publicity

Nor has the business staff been
idle. Under the leadership of Douglas Prahl, business manager, the
men have sent out circulars and
tickets to Hopkins Alumni and faculty members, blotters have been
distributed at Homewood and in the
various prep schools in the vicinity.
Posters are also being used to advertise the play.
Returns so far have been surprisingly encouraging and point to
the largest audiences in the history
of the club.
Fraternities are already reserving
seats or boxes for the performances,
and those organizations who have
not gotten in touch with Prahl are
urged to do so at once. Tickets are
already on sale at Albaugh's and
will go on sale at the Barn on Monday, March 19.
The ticket contest, now under
way, will not close until the night
of the first performance. The contest is open to every one, and three
cash prizes will be awarded. Tickets
now sold must be exchanged for reserved seats at the Barn.

SEASON SUCCESSFUL
Jays Have Won Seven Games
and Lost Equal Number
Hopkins , completely smothered
University of Baltimore's quint
under an avalanche of fouls and
field goals last Friday night at Evergreen.. The score at the end of the
half was 13-7, but the final count
totaled 42-11.
The contest resembled a real basketball game during the first half
with the speedy Silver, Diehl and
Morris putting up a battle against
the larger and more experienced
Jays. The game degenerated into
a rout during the second half, as the
University of Baltimore players
continually fouled the Hopkins
men. Many players exceeded their
quota of personal fouls and were
expelled from the game.

ProtectTheir Wind with Luckies
"We both smoke Lucky Strikes. There's a flavor we can't
resist in the toasted tobaccos. And there's another reason
we must confess. Dancing is a strenuous profession and we
watch our physical condition as zealously as does a longdistance runner. In order to be sure that our wind is always
in perfect shape we use only Luckies—the cigarette which
doesn't cut the wind."

Substitutes

Coach Darley injected many substitutes into the Hopkins line-up to
give his second-stringers a chance
to show what they could do in a
varsity game. The continuous procession to and from the bench, combined with the delays necessary for
shooting numerous fouls, rendered
the contest slow and uninteresting.
Gene Debuskey, who has played
such a sterling center game all season, went on the warpath, scoring
seven field goals and eight out of
nine foul shots for a total of twentytwo points. Johnny Lang was second high scorer, with a total of nine
points, and Silver came third, scoring five. Thirty-two fouls were
called by Referee Voith during the
contest, of which Hopkins scored
fourteen out of twenty-five and Baltimore U. three out of seven.
50-50 Season

Hopkins has won seven and lost
seven games this season, which is
much better than was expected for
the first season of basketball in six
years. The best teams in this section of the country were played and
the results have been extremely
gratifying.
The Jays opened the season with
a close win over Loyola, 26-23, and
followed up with a loss to N. Y. U.
by the same score. Virginia's five
team routed the Black and Blue,
40-25, and the St. Johns was defeated, 36-30, in an extra period.
Georgetown won from Hopkins,
36-29, but then the highly-touted
Maryland five was defeated, 22-20.
This game was the high spot in the
season, as Hopkins made a wonderful up-hill fight during the second
half to overcome a six-point lead,
and finally won out in the last few
seconds of play.

TheCreamofthe

Second Loyola Game

After defeating P. M. C., 27-23,
and losing to Washington College,
34-27, Hopkins met Loyola for the
second time. The first half ended
with the Irish on the long end of
19-8 count, but the Jays came back
to win, 33-30. Maryland conquered
Hopkins, 23-19, in a stubborn battle, and then the Jays lost to Georgetown,41-34, and to St. Johns, 27-24,
in an extra period. The rout of
Swarthmore, 56-21, and the Baltiniore U. victory ended the season.
After Friday night's game the
Hopkins squad was entertained at
Bilgers restaurant as guests of the
management.

BARNSTORMERS'
CAST SELECTED
Most of Important Roles
Picked by Coach Swindell
BOYNTON TO PLAY LEAD
Publicity and Business Staffs
Also Preparing for Play

"Benny" Boynton who will star in
The Annual Barnstormers Play

TRACK TEAM RAPIDLY
ROUNDING INTO SHAPE
Candidates Showing Good
Form in Weights and
Sprints

"Benny" Boynton will play the
leading role in the annual Barnstormer production, "The Champion," to be given at the Lyric on
Friday and Saturday evenings,
March 24-25. The remainder of
the more important roles have been
chosen by the coach, "Pop" Swindell; but who will appear in several of the minor parts is as yet undecided.
"The Champion" is a comedy of
English family life and is purported
to be the best ever selected by the
club. The plot hinges on the return of the prodigal son, but has
many clever situations that make it
unique.
Boynton will play the part of
William Burroughs, the Champion.
Other important roles 'that have
been decided on are:
Other Roles

John Burroughs, the father—H.
R. Warfield.
George Burroughs, the elder
brother—Donald White.
Lady Elifabeth Gallton—Donald
Ha me.
Antoinette, the French maid— •
Howard Caplan.
Mary, a younger sister—Roswell
Jones.
Mooney, the inn-keeper—Jerome
Natt.
Lord Brocklington—William B.
Banks.
There are several more roles, undecided as yet, that will be announced later. There are seventeen speaking parts ,altogether.
The opening curtain rises on a
scene in the Burroughs home in
Knotley, England. There are three
acts, and the setting for all. three is
laid in the same home.
When the play opens Mrs. Burroughs receives, through indirect
channels, a letter from her son, William, played by Boynton, who has
run away from home some fifteen
years ago, and who has been heard
from only occasionally in the long
interim. The prodigal, himself, follows in the wake of his letter and is

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 13, 1928

JUNIORS TO BANQUET
AT NEW HOWARD
Dr. Wight to Act as Toastmaster at Class Dinner on
March 29

•••••

Banquet season will get under
way on March 29 with the festivities of the Junior class.
The banquet, as has been previously announced, will be held at
the New Howard Hotel at seven
o'clock. Dr. Wight has been chosen toastmaster, and other speakers will be the various class officers and entertainers.
The price this year has been
set at three dollars per plate. A
man selected from each fraternity
has been placed in charge of the
tickets for this affair. These men,
upon obtaining the money; will
procure from Howard Caplan
tickets to be returned to the men
in their respective chapters upon
payment of the assessment. Samuel Hecht may also be seen in the
matter of procuring tickets.
Browne Hammond,in charge of
the entertainment committee, has
announced that Lewis Lewellyn,
of Musical Club fame, will present
several solo numbers.
To Have Dancer

A dancer has also been procured,
and from present announcements
will revive those good 'ole traditions so dear to the hearts of every
!Hopkins man, and according to
iFrisch may even establish a few
;new precedents. Other features
:have been arranged, making this
year's affair more pleasing than
'ever.
Frisch is extremely desirous
that every Junior pay up immediately so that a dependable!lumber
may be counted upon.

TENNIS PRACTICE TO
BEGIN TODAY
Kenneth C. Proctor, captain
of the tennis team, has announced that the first practice
would be held today at the
Fifth Regiment Armory at
two o'clock. Practice will be
held on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. All candidates are urged to enter the
indoor tournament at the Fifth
in order to get practice, as the
team will not have the use of
the Armory at that time.

TAU BETA PI INITIATIONS
FEATURE ASSEMBLY
Six Men Announced as New
Initiates; Mr. Walter Pagon
Also Talks
Tau Beta Pi announced the
names of six men as its initiates
at last week's assembly. The
names, as announced by Professor
A. G. Christie, who took charge
of the honorary fraternity's ceremonial part of the assembly, are:
Potter, Electrical Engineer;
Merman, Electrical
Engineer;
Hartig, Civil Engineer; Johnston,
Chemical Engineer; Roseman,
Chemical Engineer, and Nelson,
Mechanical Engineer.
To be eligible for the spring
election of the honorary organization, according to Professor
Christie,- a student must not only
be among the highest graded
eight of the senior class, but must
also be actively, interested in extra-curricular work. In the fall
selection of students, however,
those eligible are the seniors
whose grades place them in the
highest four of the class, and the
three highest graded members of
the Junior class.

Pagon Speaks

It has been rumored that Hopkins will have a "cage" some time
in the near future. The impressive
showing the basketball team has
made during the past season has
proved conclusively that there is
ample material for a ranking team
at Hopkins—the most pressing need
now is for a place in which to practice and to hold games.
Gymnasium Past

The day of the gymnasium is
fast nearing its end because of the
great amount of floor space and
money wasted on special equipment
which is seldom used. The "cage"
—which is merely one immense well
lighted room—is taking the place of
the "gym."
Dr. Goodnow, Dean Ames, and
the Board of Trustees have been
approached on the matter, but as
yet nothing definite has been decided upon. Several different types
are under consideration by those interested, none of which entail a great
amount of expense. Dr. Van Orman and Mr. Henry Iddins are unofficially in charge of the project,
but neither of them would make
any statement on the matter with
the exception that "it looks as
though we might have one."

Following the Tau Beta Pi announcement, Mr. William Walter
Pagon, who was the chief speaker
at the assembly, spoke on "Ships
Lighter Than Air," a subject concerning which he is very familiar.
The speaker gave a lecture, which
was supplemented by a series of
photographs.
'
Among the many interesting
points which Mr. Pagon emphasized was the necessity of light
but strong material in the construction of dirigibles. Mr. Pagon stated that, though the construction is very rigid, it has been
known in some cases to crumble
under the weight of an average
person.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 13, 1928

4

SCRIMMAGES HELD IN
LACROSSE PRACTICE
Many New Prospects Show
Good Form in Practice
"Scrimmages during the past
week, mainly for the purpose of getting a line on the new men, have
been of great value in showing what
we may expect in the way of
reserve material for this year and
filling vacant positions next season,"
Coach Ray Van Orman, Jay stick
mentor, said today.
"Although it should be understood that no positions are absolutely secure, what we need is strong
reserve men to carry us through the
coming hard season, in which every
lacrosse team in the country is out
for Hopkins' scalp. If Hopkins,
intercollegiate champions for the
past two years, is defeated, every
coach feels confident that the Olympics will follow."
Thirty Candidates

With more than thirty candidates
out and working hard, the Jay mentors are having a difficult job to
keep an eye on every man. However, Coaches Schmeisser, Van Orman and Darley are giving every
man a chance in scrimmage and
watching every ambitious stick
wielder carefully.
The job of net guardian, which
until this year has literally gone
begging, is being hotly contested for
by Irving Gordon, Brownley, and
Frank Cone. Cone, who is a younger brother of Max Cone, former
jay home, and Sydney Cone, clever
goalie of '25, has been displaying
clever stick work in scrimmages.
Two years ago as Park School goalkeeper he was second to none in
prep school ranks. •
In the close defense positions,
Houston, Powell, Smith, and Towlin are holding their own against
regular attackers. Houston, football end, is displaying exceptional
footwork. Powell, another football
man, is proving a veritable barrier
with his weight and speed.
On the wing defense Dal Strader,
who is just learning the stick game,
George Armstrong, and Martin Elliot are showing up well.
New Attack Men

For the attack positions Bobby
Lyons, who is also just being initiated into lacrosse; Howard Caplan,
Diffenback, Dill, and Slingluff assure coaches ample strong reserve
material. Both Caplan and Lyons
are displaying the same spirit and
talent with the stick as they did
with the pigskin.
Of last year's regulars, only
Morrill and Robinson will be out of
the line-up this spring. George
Helfrish, however, who showed
such exceptional skill two years ago
at first attack, is out again for his
old position and Caplan bids fair to
develop into a first-class third attack.

DORM DOINGS

FRANCES T. BANNON
Successor to HARBAUGH & BANNON

The recent action of the Board of
Trustees to call the dormitory
"Alumni Memorial Hall" came as a
shock to the residents. It will require several years at least for
"hall" to take the place of "dorm."
As an aid to the reformation we
suggest changing the heading of
this column from "Dorm Doings"
to "Hall Hearings" or its equivalent.
Most of the residents will agree that
the term dormitory was a misnomer
for Alumni Memorial Hall. It is
probably safe to state that the average night's rest of a resident
amounts to less than six hours. The
graduate students are the ones who
really pull the average up to six.
Graduates have been known to sleep
for days at a time. When the new
plan is well under way and only
graduates inhabit Alumni Memorial
Hall, the term dormintory will be
quite proper.

all present. The residents are indebted to Mrs. Vanneman for this
pleasing concert. This is the sort of
thing which the entertainment committee could do as well as arrange
for two or three dances a year.
There will possibly be another

TRACK PRACTICE STARTS
(Continued from Page 1, Column 4)

In the competition for berths in
the hurdle department, a lack of
good men is noticeable. Edwards
stressed the fact that men, with
speed and height combined, were
greatly in demand. The team is to
be built around the single man left
from last year's hurdlers, Vivell,
track captain.
The lack of good high hurdlers is
also noticable. A fast high hurdle
team has not existed in Hopkins for
five years, said Edwards, and great
efforts are being made to turn out
such a team this year. One man
at least should be able to take the
distance in sixteen seconds.
Poor track conditions, which existed last week, are being remedied.
Also, all the jump pits are ready
for use.

BOOKS

Third Act

The curtain rises on the third act.
What a change! English conservatism has been displaced by the flambuoyant artistry in furnishings attributed to America's newly rich.
The townspeople have gathered at
the Burroughs' home for a banquet
in honor of the Chantpion. "Drink
and be merry" seems to be the slogan of everyone in the house.
The action culminates in a fight
between William and Lord Brocklington, the latter the unscrupulous
executor of the fair Lady Elizabeth's estate. Need it be stated who
is the victor? The play ends happily, as it should ; and the Champion and Lady Elizabeth, now his
betrothed, are to make their home
in America.
The less widely advertised staffs
of the Barnstormers have been
quietly but efficiently going about
their various tasks. The scenery
has been completed and is now being painted by Bill Banks. The surprising speed shown in the completion of the "flats" is due to the
fine work of George Berry, production manager, Clyde Friz, property
manager, and their various assistants.
Publicity

Nor has the business staff been
idle. Under the leadership of Douglas Prahl, business manager, the
men have sent out circulars and
tickets to Hopkins Alumni and faculty members, blotters have been
distributed at Homewood and in the
various prep schools in the vicinity.
Posters are also being used to advertise the play.
Returns so far have been surprisingly encouraging and point to
the largest audiences in the history
of the club.
Fraternities are already reserving
seats or boxes for the performances,
and those organizations who have
not gotten in touch with Prahl are
urged to do so at once. Tickets are
already on sale at Albaugh's and
will go on sale at the Barn on Monday, March 19.
The ticket contest, now under
way, will not close until the night
of the first performance. The contest is open to every one, and three
cash prizes will be awarded. Tickets
now sold must be exchanged for reserved seats at the Barn.

University of Baltimore Team
Swamped; Score 42-11
Bowl for Your Health's Sake
SEASON SUCCESSFUL
Jays Have Won Seven Games
and Lost Equal Number
Hopkins , completely smothered
University of Baltimore's quint
under an avalanche of fouls and
field goals last Friday night at Evergreen.. The score at the end of the
half was 13-7, but the final count
totaled 42-11.
The contest resembled a real basketball game during the first half
with the speedy Silver, Diehl and
Morris putting up a battle against
the larger and more experienced
Jays. The game degenerated into
a rout during the second half, as the
University of Baltimore players
continually fouled the Hopkins
men. Many players exceeded their
quota of personal fouls and were
expelled from the game.

ProtectTheir Wind with Luckies
"We both smoke Lucky Strikes. There's a flavor we can't
resist in the toasted tobaccos. And there's another reason
we must confess. Dancing is a strenuous profession and we
watch our physical condition as zealously as does a longdistance runner. In order to be sure that our wind is always
in perfect shape we use only Luckies—the cigarette which
doesn't cut the wind."

Substitutes

Coach Darley injected many substitutes into the Hopkins line-up to
give his second-stringers a chance
to show what they could do in a
varsity game. The continuous procession to and from the bench, combined with the delays necessary for
shooting numerous fouls, rendered
the contest slow and uninteresting.
Gene Debuskey, who has played
such a sterling center game all season, went on the warpath, scoring
seven field goals and eight out of
nine foul shots for a total of twentytwo points. Johnny Lang was second high scorer, with a total of nine
points, and Silver came third, scoring five. Thirty-two fouls were
called by Referee Voith during the
contest, of which Hopkins scored
fourteen out of twenty-five and Baltimore U. three out of seven.
50-50 Season

Hopkins has won seven and lost
seven games this season, which is
much better than was expected for
the first season of basketball in six
years. The best teams in this section of the country were played and
the results have been extremely
gratifying.
The Jays opened the season with
a close win over Loyola, 26-23, and
followed up with a loss to N. Y. U.
by the same score. Virginia's five
team routed the Black and Blue,
40-25, and the St. Johns was defeated, 36-30, in an extra period.
Georgetown won from Hopkins,
36-29, but then the highly-touted
Maryland five was defeated, 22-20.
This game was the high spot in the
season, as Hopkins made a wonderful up-hill fight during the second
half to overcome a six-point lead,
and finally won out in the last few
seconds of play.

Second Loyola Game

After defeating P. M. C., 27-23,
and losing to Washington College,
34-27, Hopkins met Loyola for the
second time. The first half ended
with the Irish on the long end of
19-8 count, but the Jays came back
to win, 33-30. Maryland conquered
Hopkins, 23-19, in a stubborn battle, and then the Jays lost to Georgetown,41-34, and to St. Johns, 27-24,
in an extra period. The rout of
Swarthmore, 56-21, and the Baltiniore U. victory ended the season.
After Friday night's game the
Hopkins squad was entertained at
Bilgers restaurant as guests of the
management.
